info.game_comments:
2001 Teen Tournament semifinal game 2.
From the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia.

(1, 1).clue: Mayor Van Wyck broke ground for a tunnel to Grand Central Terminal for a subway serving this city

(2, 1).clue: Don't let it scare you but this October holiday was originally a Celtic festival for the dead

(3, 1).clue: Yeah, "Baby", this was the title of Britney's debut album

(4, 1).clue: This peanut butter cup is one of Hershey's bestselling products

(5, 1).clue: The word dungeon entered English in the 14th C. from this language's word donjon, meaning castle keep

(6, 1).clue: Traditionally, it's the section of telephone directories that lists businesses alphabetically by type

(1, 2).clue: Karl Landsteiner discovered there were 4 of these: A, B, O & AB

(2, 2).clue: That's Wright!  National Aviation Day, August 19, is celebrated on the birthday of this man

(3, 2).clue: Are they just friends?  Britney's been linked romantically to Justin Timberlake of this band

(4, 2).clue: In addition to candy, Hershey also makes Luden's, a brand of these

(5, 2).clue: The monster emerging from a dungeon here was seen in this 1931 movie

(6, 2).clue: This area of closely-cropped grass surrounds each hole in golf

(1, 3).clue: The 1st time it was held, this So. Cal. bowl game was such a rout that chariot races replaced it for the next 14 years

(2, 3).clue: We salute you if you know that this June 14 observance is a legal holiday in Pennsylvania

(3, 3).clue: Britney's song "Soda Pop" is on the soundtrack of this TV show starring Melissa Joan Hart

(4, 3).clue: Here's something to chew on: Hershey's markets the Twizzlers brand of this candy

(5, 3).clue: Jeremy Irons & Marlon Wayans starred in this 2000 adventure film based on a popular role-playing game

(6, 3).clue: These movie & TV awards are presented annually by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association

(1, 4).clue: The 1901 Platt Amendment allowed the U.S. to intervene in this formerly Spanish, now Communist island

(2, 4).clue: It's the holiday celebrated on the stamp seen here

(3, 4).clue: Sharing her small-town-girl success story, Britney wrote the book "Heart to Heart" with this family member

(4, 4).clue: Acquired in 1996, it's the classic seen here

(5, 4).clue: This "Tower" fortress built by William the Conqueror in 1078 has served as a dungeon, a zoo & a palace

(6, 4).clue: Term for the illegal buying or selling of goods in violation of rationing or price controls

(1, 5).clue: This 1904 Puccini opera partly inspired a 1980s play that just uses the letter M.

(2, 5).clue: Peter McGuire, secretary of a carpenters & joiners union, is often credited with suggesting this holiday

(3, 5).clue: At age 11, Britney joined the cast of this TV "Club" for 2 seasons

(4, 5).clue: In 1938 Nestle introduced its Crunch bar & Hershey introduced this rival

(5, 5).clue: In a Dumas novel, this "Count" unjustly spends 14 years in an island dungeon

(6, 5).clue: It's the alternate title of "Hans Brinker", the Mary Mapes Dodge tale of an impoverished Dutch boy

(1, 1).clue: While we have 23 pairs of these in each cell, the fruit fly makes do with 4, only 1 of them sex-related

(2, 1).clue: Lake Xochimilco in this North American country is only inches deep

(3, 1).clue: In it, Kirsten Dunst finds her cheerleader routines were stolen from East Compton

(4, 1).clue: Hillary Clinton succeeded her as first lady

(5, 1).clue: The family was launched to fame by Owen Tudor, an adventurer from this country of western Great Britain

(6, 1).clue: I'mlost.com sells the magnetic & gyroscopic types of this device

(1, 2).clue: 2000 news: the Gunnison sage grouse isn't just another northern sage grouse, but a new one of this classification

(2, 2).clue: Near Wilberforce University, the city of Xenia in this U.S. state is 15 miles southeast of Dayton

(3, 2).clue: As FBI agent Gracie Hart, she became Gracie Lou Freebush & was voted "Miss Congeniality"

(4, 2).clue: This actor who plays detective Sorenson replaced Jimmy Smits on "NYPD Blue"

(5, 2).clue: Elizabeth I might have personally congratulated him after the 1594 premiere of his play "Love's Labour's Lost"

(6, 2).clue: Deadyet?.com has a great page on these early Christian burial chambers near Rome

(1, 3).clue: An acre of soil contains billions of nematodes, the round type of these seen here under the microscope

(2, 3).clue: 7 miles west of Wesel in this European country is the town of Xanten on the Rhine River

(3, 3).clue: Sigourney Weaver & this actress form a party of two "Heartbreakers"

(4, 3).clue: He followed Gilbert Amelio as Apple Computer's CEO

(5, 3).clue: In brief: Born in Greenwich in 1491, becomes king at 17, has some pope problems & oh, yeah -- 6 wives

(6, 3).clue: Let'sfarm.com reviews these harvesting machines that cut & thresh grain in the field

(1, 4).clue: From the Latin for "parchment", this semi-permeable barrier surrounds a cell's cytoplasm

(2, 4).clue: You'll find the seaport of Xiamen in this Asian nation's Fujian province

(3, 4).clue: In this 2000 film Jackie Chan was in the Old West; what could be funnier?

(4, 4).clue: He took over from Ehud Barak as prime minister of Israel

(5, 4).clue: Henry Tudor reigned supreme after Richard III's death at this "Field" in 1485

(6, 4).clue: At be-a-bee!.com you can learn to build this hexagonal wax chamber

(1, 5).clue: At Prague Tech, we wonder if this physics professor's voice got higher as he moved toward you

(2, 5).clue: Flowing north through Mato Grosso state, the Xingu River covers over 1,200 miles in this South American country

(3, 5).clue: In this Dennis Quaid film, a ham radio links a father & son across time

(4, 5).clue: Seen here, he's the successor to Larry O'Brien as NBA commissioner

(5, 5).clue: Mary I's reign began in 1553 after a 9-day "interruption" by this lady, who didn't even want the crown

(6, 5).clue: At newyou!.com you can learn to transplant genes into a different type of creature & create this type of DNA

(0, 0).clue: 1 of the 2 U.S. state capitals that begin with the names of months
